fields.question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain and flattening of the medial longitudinal arch. Which ligament is most likely compromised?
A runner experiences heel pain and is diagnosed with plantar fasciitis. What structure is most directly affected?
A patient with a history of flatfoot is found to have weak muscular support for the medial arch. Which muscle is most likely underperforming?
A 50-year-old man presents with pain and deformity in the lateral longitudinal arch. Which bones are involved in this arch?
During a surgical procedure, the surgeon notes that the dorsalis pedis artery is absent. Which artery likely provides collateral circulation?
A child presents with toe-walking and tightness in the sole of the foot. Which structure is primarily responsible for maintaining the foot's arches in this condition?
A patient with diabetes has a wound on the sole of their foot over the medial arch. What nerve provides sensation to this area?
An elderly man complains of difficulty pushing off while walking. Dysfunction in which structure may contribute to this symptom?
A patient presents with pain in the medial foot and difficulty standing on tiptoes. Dysfunction in which muscle is likely?
A patient has a fracture of the calcaneus. Which arch of the foot is most likely to be affected?
A patient develops weakness in toe abduction after surgery. Which muscles are most likely affected?
A child is brought in with abnormal curvature of the feet and is diagnosed with congenital flatfoot. Which structure is most likely deficient?
A basketball player has a sprain that compromises the stability of the transverse arch. Which structure primarily supports this arch?
A patient has difficulty extending the big toe. Dysfunction in which nerve is most likely responsible?
A woman reports heel pain with tenderness over the plantar aponeurosis. Which condition is most consistent with her symptoms?
A patient with nerve injury shows loss of sensation in the lateral sole of the foot. Which nerve is damaged?
A patient has reduced blood flow in the dorsalis pedis artery. Which pulse point should the clinician palpate to confirm this?
fields.option1: Dorsum of the foot between the first and second metatarsals

fields.question_text: A child with congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) is treated surgically. Which aspect of the foot is primarily corrected?
A patient has pain along the first metatarsal and hallux. Examination reveals dysfunction of a tendon supporting the medial arch. Which tendon is affected?
A patient presents with pain and deformity in the lateral sole. Which ligament is likely involved?
Which ligament provides primary support for the medial longitudinal arch?
Which muscle primarily supports the transverse arch?
Which artery is the continuation of the anterior tibial artery?
Which nerve supplies the medial two-thirds of the sole of the foot?
Which artery forms the plantar arterial arch with the lateral plantar artery?
Which structure is a thick fibrous band supporting the foot arches?
Which ligament stabilizes the lateral longitudinal arch?
Which nerve supplies most of the intrinsic muscles of the sole?
Which muscles are responsible for toe abduction?
Which artery is palpated on the dorsum of the foot between the first and second metatarsals?
Which nerve provides sensation to the lateral third of the sole?
A patient presents with a flat shoulder and inability to abduct the arm between 15 and 90. Which nerve is most likely damaged?
During a surgical procedure in the axilla, the surgeon accidentally damages the thoracodorsal nerve. Which muscle's function would be most affected?
A patient has difficulty flexing and medially rotating the arm. Which part of the deltoid muscle is most likely affected?
A patient sustains an injury to the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
During a mastectomy, the surgeon notices damage to the lateral thoracic artery. Which structure's blood supply is most compromised?
A patient presents with weakness in supination of the forearm and flexion of the elbow. Which nerve is most likely injured?
A patient has a stab wound in the axilla, damaging the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. Which nerve is most likely affected?
A patient is unable to extend the elbow after a fracture of the humerus. Which artery is most likely compromised?
A patient presents with winging of the scapula. Which nerve is most likely damaged?
A patient has a lesion affecting the medial cord of the brachial plexus. Which nerve is most likely affected?
A patient has a tumor compressing the axillary vein. Which vein is most likely to be affected first?
A patient has a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. Which artery is most at risk of injury?
A patient has a lesion affecting the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. Which nerve is most likely affected?
A patient has a stab wound in the axilla, damaging the subscapular artery. Which muscle's blood supply is most compromised?
A patient has a lesion affecting the posterior circumflex humeral artery. Which structure is most at risk of ischemia?
A patient has a lesion affecting the musculocutaneous nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the radial nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the median nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the ulnar nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the axillary nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the long thoracic nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the thoracodorsal nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the suprascapular nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
fields.option1: A. Lateral rotation of the arm
fields.option2: B. Medial rotation of the arm

fields.question_text: A patient has a lesion affecting the subscapular nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
fields.option1: A. Medial rotation of the arm
fields.option2: B. Lateral rotation of the arm

fields.question_text: A patient has a lesion affecting the lateral pectoral nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the medial pectoral nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the dorsal scapular nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the nerve to subclavius. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
A patient has a lesion affecting the lower subscapular nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
fields.option1: A. Medial rotation of the arm
fields.option2: B. Lateral rotation of the arm

fields.question_text: A patient has a lesion affecting the upper subscapular nerve. Which action is most likely to be impaired?
fields.option1: A. Medial rotation of the arm
fields.option2: B. Lateral rotation of the arm

fields.question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for difficulty keeping up with his peers. Examination reveals muscle weakness beginning in the pelvic girdle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A teenager presents with mild muscle weakness that started in childhood and progressed slowly. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the dystrophin gene. What is the most likely condition?
A 6-year-old boy with Duchenne muscular dystrophy shows calf pseudohypertrophy. What causes this finding?
fields.option1: Replacement of muscle tissue with adipose and fibrotic tissue
fields.option4: Increased blood flow to the calf muscles

fields.question_text: A patient presents with muscle pain and weakness after consuming excessive alcohol. Lab results show rhabdomyolysis. What complication is most concerning?
A 55-year-old woman presents with proximal muscle weakness and a heliotrope rash. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient with polymyositis is treated with corticosteroids. What is the underlying mechanism of muscle damage in this condition?
fields.option3: Accumulation of toxic metabolites in muscles

fields.question_text: A patient complains of fluctuating muscle weakness and drooping eyelids. Antibodies to acetylcholine receptors are detected. What condition does this patient have?
A 70-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness. Muscle biopsy shows rimmed vacuoles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient with small cell lung carcinoma develops proximal muscle weakness. Which disorder is most likely associated with this condition?
A newborn male presents with elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. What is the pathogenesis of this condition?
fields.option1: Mutation in the dystrophin gene disrupting the dystrophin-glycoprotein complex
fields.option3: Accumulation of rimmed vacuoles in myofibers

fields.question_text: A patient with chronic statin use complains of muscle pain and weakness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 45-year-old woman presents with muscle weakness, pain, and a rash on her eyelids. What is a distinguishing feature of this condition on biopsy?
A 12-year-old boy presents with difficulty walking and an enlarged calf. What laboratory finding is most likely elevated?
A patient with thyrotoxicosis develops proximal muscle weakness. What is the most likely cause of their symptoms?
A patient with dermatomyositis has a paraneoplastic syndrome. What is the underlying cause?
A male child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy is at risk of cardiac complications. What is the most likely pathology?
A patient with muscle weakness is diagnosed with Lambert-Eaton syndrome. What is the underlying mechanism?
A patient presents with rhabdomyolysis after excessive alcohol consumption. What is the primary cause of renal failure in this condition?
A patient with long-term corticosteroid use develops muscle weakness. What type of myopathy is most likely?
A patient with myasthenia gravis reports significant improvement after taking anticholinesterase medication. What is the mechanism of action?
Which myopathy is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and occurs with thyrotoxicosis?
Which protein is defective in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
Which muscle disorder is associated with antibodies to presynaptic calcium channels?
What histological finding is characteristic of inclusion body myositis?
Which inflammatory myopathy is most common in children?
Which drug class is most commonly associated with drug-induced myopathy?
What is the primary autoimmune target in myasthenia gravis?
What is the hallmark pathological feature of polymyositis?
Which condition is most strongly associated with small cell lung carcinoma?
What is the most common cause of death in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
Which inflammatory myopathy is common in patients over 60 years old?
A 32-year-old runner complains of pain on the medial side of her lower leg. Examination reveals inflammation of the primary weight-bearing bone in the leg. Which bone is affected?
A hiker falls and fractures the lateral malleolus. Which bone is involved?
A 45-year-old man presents with difficulty dorsiflexing his foot and numbness between his first and second toes. Which nerve is likely injured?
A patient is diagnosed with foot drop and is unable to dorsiflex the foot. Which compartment of the leg contains the affected muscles?
A construction worker suffers a deep laceration to the lateral compartment of the leg. Which nerve is most likely affected?
A patient presents with inability to evert the foot. Which muscle group is likely affected?
A 70-year-old man complains of pain and swelling in the posterior leg. Examination reveals a ruptured calcaneal tendon. Which action is impaired?
A patient has numbness over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which nerve is most likely involved?
A motorcyclist sustains a fracture to the fibular neck. Which nerve is at risk of injury?
A patient complains of pain and inability to extend the toes. Which muscle group is most likely affected?
A runner complains of shin pain during activity. Inflammation of which structure is most likely responsible?
A patient has difficulty flexing the toes and inversion of the foot. Which compartment of the leg is affected?
A patient with a fractured tibia has damage to the popliteal artery. Which area of the leg is most at risk of ischemia?
A patient suffers from deep vein thrombosis in the posterior tibial vein. Which condition is most likely to develop?
A patient presents with weakness in plantarflexion and sensory loss in the sole of the foot. Which nerve is damaged?
A patient is unable to unlock the knee joint during flexion. Which muscle is affected?
A fracture of the tibia results in damage to the nutrient artery. Which structure is most affected?
A patient complains of numbness in the web space between the first and second toes. Which nerve is affected?
A patient presents with pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient has a fracture involving the interosseous membrane of the leg. Which two bones are connected by this structure?
Which bone forms the medial malleolus?
Which nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment of the leg?
Which artery supplies the anterior compartment of the leg?
Which compartment of the leg contains the tibialis posterior muscle?
Which muscle is the strongest dorsiflexor of the foot?
Which vein drains into the small saphenous vein?
Which nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral side of the leg and foot?
Which artery divides into the posterior tibial and fibular arteries?
Which muscle acts to unlock the knee joint?
Which structure connects the tibia and fibula along their length?

A patient with a history of osteoarthritis presents with persistent knee pain. His physician prescribes an NSAID for pain relief. After a few weeks, the patient complains of stomach pain and dark stools. Which NSAID is most likely to cause these symptoms?

A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and cardiovascular disease is prescribed an NSAID for joint pain. The physician chooses celecoxib over other NSAIDs. What is the primary reason for this choice?

A 40-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and is prescribed diclofenac. A week later, she develops mild swelling in her feet and increased blood pressure. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
fields.option1: Fluid retention due to NSAID use

fields.question_text: A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease (CKD) needs pain management for osteoarthritis. Which NSAID should be avoided in this patient?
A 10-year-old boy with a viral fever is given aspirin by his parents. He later develops vomiting, confusion, and liver dysfunction. Which condition is most likely responsible?
A patient with a history of gout presents with an acute flare. The physician prescribes an NSAID instead of aspirin. What is the primary reason aspirin is avoided?
fields.option4: It has a weaker analgesic effect

fields.question_text: A 50-year-old man taking low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular protection develops gastrointestinal discomfort. Which medication can be co-prescribed to reduce this adverse effect?
A patient presents with acute pain and swelling after a sports injury. His physician prescribes ibuprofen. What is the mechanism of action of ibuprofen?
fields.option2: Irreversible inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2
fields.option3: Reversible inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2

fields.question_text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of myocardial infarction is on aspirin therapy. She accidentally takes a high dose and presents with tinnitus, hyperventilation, and metabolic acidosis. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A patient develops hypertension after prolonged NSAID use. What is the most likely cause?

fields.topic: Front and medial aspect of thigh
